choices.text: Involve whole of the membranous part of the vocal cords
Patient has a low pitch voice
Voice rest and Corticosteroids are the mainstay of management

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented with complain of hoarseness of voice. He was a chronic smoker. His endoscopy examination reveals following features. Picture given below. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms the diagnosis in this case is Rienke's oedema.

This is a chronic and irreversible oedema of the Rienke's space. It involves sub mucosal space of the membranous true vocal cords along their free medial margin. (Option A)

It can occur due to any chronic irritation of larynx most commonly due to smoking hence also known as smoker's larynx. (Option C)

Other irritants such as voice abuse, acid reflux and post nasal drip can also cause this.

Patient presents with low pitch voice, effortful speaking and hoarseness. (Option B)

Diffuse symmetrical pale swelling is seen on the free edges of both the vocal cords.

Management - Cessation of smoking, Voice therapy and Reduction glottoplasty if required.

Key Takeaway:

Reinke's edema aka smoker's larynx is chronic and irreversible oedema of whole of membranous part of vocal cord. Patient present with low pitch voice, hoarseness and managed with Cessation of smoking, Voice therapy and Reduction glottoplasty if required.

Image reference: Voice surgeon website.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with complain of persistent of boy like high pitch voice. His all friends has developed adult like low pitch voice. On examination his thyroid prominence was pressed backwards and downwards which lead to production of low pitch voice. Picture given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The test described in the question is called Gutzmann pressure test. The condition in which it is performed is called puberophonia.

At puberty the high pitch voice of a boy changes to the low pitch voice of an adult male.

This occurs due to lengthening and relaxation of the vocal cords. If the low pitch voice fails to develop the adult male continues to have a high pitched voice.

It is usually seen in introverts and emotionally insecure males.

If these patients produce a low pitch voice on pressing the thyroid prominence downwards and backwards then they should be treated with surgical method. This is known as Gutzmann pressure test.

Surgical management includes type 3 thyroplasty which is procedure of relaxing the vocal cords by shortening it anteroposteriorly.

Option B: Androphonia has characteristic low pitch sounds.

Option C: Hysterical Aphonia Presents in mostly Female pt. Patient present with No VC adduction on speech & VC movement on cough. Managed with Psychotherapy and reassurance.

Option D: Spasmodic dysphonia is a neurological voice disorder that causes involuntary spasms in the muscles of the larynx. These spasms can disrupt the flow of air through the vocal folds, resulting in a strained, strangled, or breathy voice.

Key Takeaway:

Puberphonia or mutational Falsetto:

  • C/o: Adult male patient having a high pitched voice.
  • O/E: Gutzmann's pressure's test Larynx pushed posteriorly & downwards Low pitched voice.
  • Mx: Type III thyroplasty

Image reference: laryngopedia.

choices.text: It is a local laryngeal disorder
It may be associated with other focal dystopia
Adductor groups are having the strangulated voice while abductor type is having the breathe voice
Botulinum toxins is used in the treatment

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presented with complain of scratchy creaky voice. On examination, the vocal cords were found to be having Adductor Spasmodic dysphonia. All are true about this condition except?
questions.solution:
Adductor Spasmodic dysphonia is a neurological disorder and not a local laryngeal disorder. Thus option A is wrong.

Spasmodic dystonia or laryngeal dystonia is a condition where the phonatory muscles go into involuntary spasm during the speech leading to dysphonia.

It is often associated with other dystonia, eg blepharospasm, oromandibular dystonia. (Option B)

Adductor spasm: it is more common. Here the Adductor muscle goes into spasm during the speech. It develops scratchy, creaky voice.

Abductor spasm: Here the abductor muscle goes into spasm, causing opening up of vocal cords. This leads to breathe whispery voice. (Option C)

Management: percutaneous botulinum toxins injection in the muscles involved is the main treatment. (Option D)

In Adductor spasm toxin is given in the thyroarytenoid muscle. In the abductor spasm, it is given in posterior cricoarytenoid muscle.

Key Takeaway:

Spasmodic Dysphonia -

  • Neurological Disorder aw Focal Dystonia.
  • Adductor Spasm - Scratchy Voice Relieved with Thyroarytenoid Muscle botulinum injection
  • Vs Abductor - Breathy Voice relieved with Posterior Cricoarytenoid Botulinum Injection.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with hoarseness voice and stridor. Following a normal vaginal delivery, this child received all the routine immunization. Endoscopic picture of larynx is given below. Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Juvenile laryngeal papillomatosis is the most common benign tumor seen in the child of 2 to 5 years of age. It is caused by human pailloma virus. HPV subtypes 6 and 11. HPV 11 being more aggressive.

Transmission to neonate occurs through contact with mother's birth canal during vaginal delivery.

The papilloma starts at the true vocal cords as seen in the endoscopic picture and later on spreads to involve whole of larynx. They are multiple and even reach the mouth, pharynx, trachea and lower respiratory tract.

Management involves microlaryngoscopy excision / debulking by microdebrider, co2, laser, cup forceps or cryosurgery. The most accepted and Gold standard means is microdebrider.

Chances of recurrence are very high so repeated excision is required. In post operative period alpha interferon, bevacizumab, and cidofovir has shown to decrease chance of recurrence.

Key Takeaway:

Juvenile Laryngeal Papillomatosis

  • Benign Tumor in children Due to HPV 6, 11
  • Managed with Microlaryngeal Excision.
  • To prevent recurrence - Alpha Interferon, Bevacizumab, Cidofovir.

Image reference: Massachusetts general hospital website.

choices.text: He should be given radical radiotherapy as this can cure early tumor
He should be treated with a combination of radiotherapy and chemotherapy
He should first receive radiotherapy and if residual tumor is present then should undergo laryngectomy.
He should first undergo laryngectomy and then postoperative radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient was diagnosed as having carcinoma of larynx. His CT Scan was suggestive of involvement of anterior commissure and right vocal cord. He also developed perichondritis of thyroid cartilage. Which of the following statement is true for management in this case?
questions.solution:
Thyroid cartilage perichondritis indicates invasion of thyroid cartilage.

Invasion of thyroid cartilage means T4a tumor. Total laryngectomy followed by radiotherapy is used as a modality for stage 4a tumor. With thyroid cartilage invasion.

T1 - tumor is limited to one subsite of glottis.

T2 - tumor extending to adjacent subsites, normal vocal cord mobility.

T3 - vocal cord fixation or spread to preepiglottic or paraglottic space With minor thyroid cartilage invasion.

T4a - Tumor invades through thyroid cartilage or tissue beyond larynx locally, trachea, strap muscles and esophagus.

T4b - tumor invades beyond the larynx to distant places, prevertebral space, carotid etc.

Key Takeaway:

Laryngeal cancer stage 4a Treated with total laryngectomy with adjuvant radiotherapy.

choices.text: Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice
It is more common in 15 to 30 years of age.

questions.text: A 5-year-old female child presented with complain of Hoarseness of voice. Her Laryngoscopic endoscopy examination was done. Picture is given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms the diagnosis in this case is Juvenile laryngeal papillomatosis.

It is the most common benign tumor seen in childrens. It is commonly seen in between the age of 2 to 5 years. (Option C)

It is caused by human papilloma virus HPV the HPV 6 and 11 strains are common subtypes. HPV 11 been the more aggressive. (Option A)

Transmission occurs to child from the mother during the vaginal delivery. It presents with hoarseness of voice and abnormal cry.

Malignant transformation can occur thus it is considered as premalignant condition. (Option D)

Treatment includes Microlaryngoscopic removal using laser or cold steel or Microdebrider. Recurrence rate is very high. (Option B)

Key Takeaway:

Juvenile Laryngeal Papillomatosis

  • Benign Tumor in children Due to HPV 6, 11
  • Managed with Microlaryngeal Excision.
  • To prevent recurrence - Alpha Interferon, Bevacizumab, Cidofovir.

Image reference: Springer link website.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient known case of SCC supraglottis. His CT Scan shows tumor extending from right side valleculae and involving epiglottis. Vocal cords are mobile. No cervical lymph nodes are seen. No distant metastasis seen. What will be the appropriate management in this case?
questions.solution:
Tumor Grading:

T1 - tumor is limited to one subsite of glottis.

T2 - tumor extending to adjacent subsites, normal vocal cord mobility.

T3 - vocal cord fixation or spread to preepiglottic or paraglottic space With minor thyroid cartilage invasion.

T4a - Tumor invades through thyroid cartilage or tissue beyond larynx locally, trachea, strap muscles and esophagus.

T4b - tumor invades beyond the larynx to distant places, prevertebral space, carotid etc.

Based on the above extension, the stage here will be T2N0M0 which is stage 2.

Key Takeaway:

Laryngeal cancer stage 2 treated with external beam radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient known case of carcinoma larynx. His endoscopy and Ct scan reveals that the tumour is involving both side vocal cords but mobility of vocal cords is normal. Tumour is not extending into any other regions of larynx. What will be the T staging in this case?
questions.solution:
Tumour is limited to the vocal cords only with normal mobility suggesting of T1 stage. Moreover, it involves both vocal cords thus stage is T1b.

Tis: Tis means tumour in situ. The cancer is very early. It is in the top layer of cells that line the vocal cords and has not spread into any surrounding tissue.

T1: T1 means the cancer has grown deeper but is still within the vocal cords. T1 is divided into 2 stages:

T1a means the cancer is in one vocal cord but the vocal cords can move normally.

T1b means the cancer is in both vocal cords but they can move normally.

T2: T2 means the cancer has grown into the area above the vocal cords (supraglottis) or below the vocal cords (subglottis), or both areas. The vocal cords might not be able to move as normal.

T3: T3 can mean one or all of the below. The cancer:

  • is still in the voice box (larynx) but has stopped a vocal cord from moving (your doctor may call this vocal cord fixation)
  • has grown into a fat filled space on either side of the voice box (paraglottic space)
  • has grown into the inner part of the cartilage that protects the vocal cords (thyroid cartilage)

T4: T4 is divided into 2 stages:

T4a means one or all of the below. The cancer has grown:

  • through the outer part of the thyroid cartilage
  • into the tissues outside the voice box, such as the windpipe, soft tissues of the neck, deep muscles of the tongue, the thyroid gland or food pipe (oesophagus)

T4a cancer of the larynx is also called moderately advanced local disease.

T4b means:

  • the cancer has grown into the space before the spine (prevertebral space), around a blood vessel called the carotid artery, or structures in the space between the lungs (the mediastinum)

T4b cancer of the larynx is also called a very advanced local disease.

Key Takeaway:

Tumour is limited to the vocal cords only with normal mobility suggesting of T1 stage. Moreover it is involving both vocal cords thus stage is T1b.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with the history of accidentally ingesting/inhaling a coin. His X-ray AP and lateral view are given. Based on the X-ray what is the site of lodgement of the coin?
questions.solution:
In the above X-ray the foreign body shadow appears to be linear in the AP view and Round on the lateral view which is suggestive of foreign body to be inside Trachea.

In this X-ray air shadow of the Trachea can also be seen and the foreign body appears inside this shadow which further confirms the findings.

Option B: Foreign body shadow in oesophagus appears Round on AP view and linear on lateral view plus the foreign body appears behind the shadow of trachea.

Option C: Foreign body in cricopharynx also appears Round in AP view and linear on lateral view. The position is much higher than the shadow of trachea.

Other clinical features suggesting Foreign body inside trachea includes sudden onset of wheeze, expiratory stridor, atelectasis of involved lung.

Management includes Removal of Foreign body through bronchoscopy.

Key Takeaway:

Image reference: Radiopedia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient who was in ICU was having intubation since 10 days. Tracheostomy was performed in him. Picture is given below. At what level the tracheostomy tube is inserted?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the above picture is called Tracheostomy.

It is a procedure in which an opening is made on the anterior wall of the Trachea. It can be planned or emergency.

This procedure is done in rose position. After the skin incision, the strap muscles and pre Tracheal fascia is separated.

Finally a vertical incision is made in the midline on the 2nd and 3rd Tracheal rings. This is described as mid tracheostomy. Mid tracheostomy is done in most cases. (Option B)

When the incision is made on the 1st Tracheal ring it is called high tracheostomy. High tracheostomy is done for carcinoma of larynx (Option A)

If it is made below 4th ring, it is called low tracheostomy. Low tracheostomy is done in laryngeal stenosis. (Option C & D)

Key Takeaway: In Majority Cases Mid tracheostomy is performed which is done at 2nd & 3rd tracheal rings.

Image reference: Healthline website.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with history of accidentally ingesting/inhaling coin. His Xray Ap and lateral view is given below. What is the site of lodgement of this coin?
questions.solution:
Foreign body shadow in oesophagus appears Round on AP view and linear on lateral view plus the foreign body appears behind the shadow of trachea.

Option A & C: In the above Xray the shadow of the coin is seen below the level of larynx and oropharynx.

Option D: Moreover in the above Xray the shadow of the coin can be clearly seen behind the shadow of the Trachea.

Key Takeaway:

Image reference: Academic life in Emergency medicine website

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with spasm of all the muscles of body. Tetanus was suspected in this case. Emergency tracheostomy has to be done in this case to secure the airway. Which of the following structures are not at risk of damage in Emergency tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
The inferior thyroid artery goes under the surface of thyroid gland thus they Do not get injured during tracheostomy procedure. Rest all the structures can get injured.

Complications of tracheostomy are:

  • Haemorrhage because of thyroidea ima artery. (Option C)
  • Subcutaneous emphysema This can occur either because of large Tracheal opening and leakage of air or because of tight suture.
  • Pneumothorax: injury to apical pleura.
  • Injury to adjacent structures: Injury to Inferior thyroid vein, isthmus of thyroid. Inferior thyroid artery does not get injured as it runs under the thyroid. (Options A & D)
  • Tube displacement and obstruction.

Key Takeaway:

The inferior thyroid artery goes under the surface of thyroid gland thus they Do not get injured during tracheostomy procedure.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient a case of carcinoma larynx presented 6 months after completion of his radiotherapy. Patients case sheet showed that he was given radiation in the dose of 1.8 to 2.25 Gy. It was given once a day for five days in a week. What kind of fractionation was used in this patient?
questions.solution:
The paramount goal of patient care is to optimize treatment efficacy, while minimizing toxicity.

It was seen that instead of giving a single large dose of radiation if the dose is divided into multiple fractions, it improved the recovery of the normal tissue. This is called fractionation.

Conventional fractionation: it implies dose per fractionation of 1.8 to 2.25Gy, given once a day, five fractions in a week. (Option B)

Hypo fractionation: Dose per fractionation is more than 2.25 Gy given once daily five fractions a week. (Option A)

Hyper fractionation: Total number of doses are increased but are delivered using multiple fractions per day. The dose per fraction Is slightly reduced. (Option C)

Accelerated fractionation: Overall treatment time is significantly reduced, the total dose per fraction and the number of fractions are either unchanged or sometimes reduced. (Option D)

Key Takeaway:

Conventional fractionation implies 1.8 to 2.25Gy dose per fractionation of given once a day, five fractions in a week.

choices.text: Stabilizes microtubules to block M phase

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient known case of carcinoma of Pyriform fossa with invasion of thyroid cartilage was decided to be given chemotherapy. Cisplatin and 5 fluorouracil was started in this patient. What is the mechanism of action of cisplatin?
questions.solution:
With better understanding of the impact of multimodality treatment, chemotherapy is used as both definitive and adjuvant regimens. The mechanism of action of the various drugs used in head and neck SCC are as follows.

Option A - Platinum Compound cisplatin and Carboplatin - forms DNA cross links.

Option B - Taxane - paclitaxel and docetaxel - stabilizes microtubules to block M phase.

Option C - Antifolate - Methotrexate - inhibits DHFR during S phase.

Option D - Fluoropyrimidine - 5 Fluorouracil - inhibits during S phase.

Key Takeaway:

Platinum Compound like Cisplatin & Carboplatin acts via forming DNA cross links.

choices.text: The incidence of xerostomia is higher in intensity modulated radiation therapy
The advantage of IMRT is that it minimizes damage to the surrounding normal structure
It uses an advanced form of 3d CRT
Non uniform radiation beam intensity is used to deliver the dose confirming to geometry of the target organ.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient known case of carcinoma larynx T1N0M0 was advised to undergo Intensity modulated radiation therapy. Which of the following statements about intensity modulated radiation therapy is not true?
questions.solution:
Intensity modulated radiation therapy is an advanced form of 3d CRT that is advantageous for the treatment of most head and neck cancers. (Option C)

Three dimensional planning is based upon information obtained from CT scans in contrast to older techniques.

After defining the target volumes and organs at risk, the planning objectives is fed into planning systems, which will generate a treatment plan by multiple iterations, by a process called inverse planning.

Non uniform radiation beam intensities are used to deliver the dose confirming to the geometry of the target organ. The dose to the critical structure can be kept below their tolerance limits. (Option D)

The main benefit of the IMRT is that it reduces the damage to the surrounding normal structures. (Option B)

The benefit of IMRT in preventing xerostomia is demonstrated in many clinical trials. (Option A)

Key Takeaway: The incidence of xerostomia is lower in intensity modulated radiation therapy compared to older techniques due to minimal damage to surroundin structures.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient known case of carcinoma tongue underwent Hemiglossectomy with Modified radical neck dissection. His primary tumour and excised lymph nodes were sent for histopathology examination. In which of the following condition adjuvant radiotherapy will not be required by the patient?
questions.solution:
Multiple lymph node involvement is an indication of Adjuvant radiotherapy and not single lymph node involvement.

Indications of Adjuvant radiotherapy:

  • Advanced stage T3 or T4. (Option D)
  • Presence of lymphovascular invasion
  • Presence of Perineural invasion
  • Positive surgical margins (Option B)
  • Multiple lymph node involvement
  • Extra capsular nodal extension. (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

Indications of Adjuvant radiotherapy in Tongue carcinoma:

  • Advanced stage T3 or T4.
  • Presence of lymphovascular invasion
  • Presence of Perineural invasion
  • Positive surgical margins
  • Multiple lymph node involvement
  • Extra capsular nodal extension.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient known case of carcinoma larynx of T3, N1 and M0 stage underwent a full course of concurrent chemotherapy radiotherapy. Even after complete course, the patient shows presence of residual disease. What should be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Option A: Regular monthly follow up is enough if no residual / Recurrent disease.

Option C & D: Repeat Chemoradiation & Radiotherapy alone has no role in managing Recurrence if concurrent Chemoradiation used initially.

Key Takeaway: Stage T3N1MO with Recurrent Disease managed with Salvage Laryngectomy with transesophageal puncture.

choices.text: Squamous element of brachial remnants in lymph nodes turning malignant.
Subclinical primary with nodal metastasis, either due to faster growth rate of the nodal metastasis or sloughing of necrotic carcinoma.
Primary regressing due to immune hyperactivity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male smoker patient presented with mass on left side of neck at level 2 region. Fnac was done which was suggestive of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma. A careful endoscopic, radiological examination was done which revealed absence of any primary tumor. Which of the following is not a theory for this condition?
questions.solution:
The incidence of a neck node with unknown primary origin in head and neck region is about 3%.

Carcinoma of unknown primary is defined as histological confirmation of atleast one of the cervical lymph node to be metastatic, in the absence of primary tumor. Which is confirmed by thorough physical, endoscopic and radiological examination.

Theories of occurrence includes:

  1. squamous element of brachial remnants in lymph nodes turning malignant. (Option A)
  2. subclinical primary with nodal metastasis, either due to faster growth rate of the nodal metastasis or slouching of necrotic carcinoma. (Option B)
  3. primary regressing due to immune hyperactivity. (Option C)
  4. small hidden primary in tonsil/base of tongue crypts with aggressive nodal metastasis.

Key Takeaway:

Theories of Carcinoma of unknown primary with Neck Nodes

  • Squamous element of branchial element
  • Subclinical / Hidden primary with aggressive nodal metastasis
  • Primary Regressing due to immune hyperactivity.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is a known case of metastatic neck node with unknown primary origin. His CT Scan shows metastasis in multiple nodes on ipsilateral side of neck. None of the node is larger than 6cm in greatest dimension. What will be the appropriate line of management in this case?
questions.solution:
Metastasis in multiple nodes in the Ipsilateral side is suggestive of stage N2B.

Key Takeaway: Head & Neck tumours with Stage 2b are managed with Chemoradiation if post treatment positive PET Scan then salvage Neck Dissection Is done.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is known case of squamous cell carcinoma of temporal bone. His HRCT temporal bone shows tumour with erosion of bone limited to the External auditory canal without involving the entire thickness. What will be the T staging in this case according to Modified Pittsburgh staging?
questions.solution:
According to modified Pittsburgh staging:

  1. T1 - Tumor limited to the EAC without bony erosion or evidence of soft tissue involvement
  2. T2 - Tumor with limited EAC bone erosion (not full thickness) with limited (< 0.5 cm) soft tissue involvement
  3. T3 - Tumor eroding the osseous EAC (full thickness) with limited (< 0.5 cm) soft tissue involvement or tumor involving the middle ear, mastoid, or both
  4. T4 - Tumor eroding the cochlea, petrous apex, medial wall of the middle ear, carotid canal, or jugular foramen of dura; or with extensive soft tissue involvement (>0.5 cm), such as involvement of the temporomandibular joint or stylomastoid foramen; or with evidence of facial paresis.

Key Takeaway:

According to modified Pittsburgh Staging tumour with erosion of bone limited to the External auditory canal without involving the entire thickness is Stage T2.

choices.text: Blind biopsy from nasopharynx, base of tongue, pyriform fossa, tonsillectomy
Radiotherapy or radical/ Modified neck dissection
Pan/triple endoscopy Nasopharyngoscopy, esophagoscopy and laryngoscopy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with complain of swelling over neck since 2 months. A complete ENT examination and head and neck examination was done which shows no any significant findings. He was advised FNAC which shows metastatic squamous cell carcinoma. What should be the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
Although All Options are to be Performed Triple Endoscopy has Priority among given options.

Secondary lymph node enlargement of the neck where primary cannot be detected is known as occult primary with secondary neck.

It should be worked up as follows:

  • Complete ENT examination and head and neck examination
  • FNAC of neck node showing metastatic squamous cell carcinoma
  • Pan/ triple endoscopy Nasopharyngoscopy, esophagoscopy and laryngoscopy
  • Ct /MRI of head and neck
  • Pet scan
  • Blind biopsy from nasopharynx, base of tongue, pyriform fossa, tonsillectomy.
  • Radiotherapy or radical neck dissection followed by radiotherapy.

Key Takeaway:

Stepladder Approach of Occult Primary in ENT:

Clinical Examination - FNAC of Neck Nodes - Triple Endoscopy - CT / MRI - PET Scan - Blind Biopsy from Various Regions - Radiotherapy / Radical Neck Dissection.

Image reference: Research gate journal.
